title: Tyrone Mings details England's half-time discussion after Bulgaria racist abuse
text:
Tyrone Mings suffered horrific racial abuse on his England debut (Picture: Getty Images)

Tyrone Mings says the England players and management made a ‘unified decision’ to play the second half against Bulgaria after suffering racist abuse through the first half of the match.

England won the game 6-0 in Sofia, but it was marred by Bulgaria fans making monkey noises and giving Nazi salutes, which caused the match to be stopped twice during the first half after complaints from the English players.

Gareth Southgate’s side were considering not going out for the second half due to the abysmal behaviour of the Bulgaria fans, but Mings, who was making his debut for his country and was subjected to the abuse, says they unanimously decided that finishing the game was the right thing to do.

‘We had a conversation regarding did we want to go back out, and everyone made a unified decision to go back out and play,’ Mings told talkSPORT.

‘I think it was important that we highlighted it [the abuse], because unfortunately there are people that get racially abused who don’t have a voice.

‘So I think it was important for us to highlight it and make sure the appropriate people were aware it was going on.

Bulgaria fans give Nazi salutes during the game with England (Picture: Getty Images)

‘But then after that it was important that we just played football. Everybody made the decision and everybody stood together and everybody ultimately came through the game and we were proud of our performance.

‘It’s happened before but we have protocols in place which helped throughout the game.

‘It’s difficult; I don’t want to categorise the whole country by saying that its racist, but there were obviously elements of the crowd making those chants.

‘But the second half was a lot better. I don’t know if it was a turning point, but hopefully.’

Southgate praised the officials for dealing with the situation appropriately and also believes that by at least pausing the game in the first half, his players made a statement.

‘It’s an unacceptable situation,’ Southgate told ITV. ‘I think we’ve made two statements really by winning the game but also we have raised the awareness of everybody to the situation.

‘The game was stopped twice and I know for some people that won’t be enough. But I think we as a group were on board with that process.’

The England boss did say that if any further racist abuse in the second half would have led to his side leaving the field and probably not returning.

England’s performance on the field was exceptional given the circumstances, as Raheem Sterling and Ross Barkley both scored twice, while Marcus Rashford and Harry Kane also got on the score sheet.
